newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: FEATURE - Chinese-born MP gives NZ politics new voice.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Chinese-born MP gives NZ politics new voice.

text.p: A hundred and thirty years after Chinese immigrants first sailed to New Zealand to mine for gold, the country finally has its first Asian-born member of parliament.
Chinese-born Pansy Wong is walking an untrodden path -- providing a strong voice for a once silent community.
"My election has led them to a very heightened interest in the whole political debate, which is fantastic," she said of the country's 185,000-strong Asian community.

"They see electing one of their own candidates as a symbol that Asians are part of New Zealand. A symbol that in New Zealand everything is possible if you put your work into it. It really doesn't matter where you come from."
Wong, 41, won a seat for the conservative National Party in a general election last month which produced a hung parliament. National remains as caretaker government while coalition talks drag on.
Her background, with its elements of struggle and tenacity, echoes the stories of many immigrants.
Born in Shanghai, Wong and her family escaped the oppression of Maoist China for Hong Kong, before making a further move in 1974 for a better life in New Zealand.
"The family joke was my father 'discovered' New Zealand," Wong told Reuters in her small office in a parliamentary annex brimming with the influx of new MPs.
He was working in the Chinese shipping industry and New Zealand was one of the countries he visited.
"He...believes it is a good place for family, for future. We don't practice democratic voting in the family and when Dad decided, that's it," she laughed with her characteristic humour.
With a Chinese name meaning 'fragrant flower', 19-year-old Pansy trained as an accountant at a New Zealand university where she met her future husband, Malaysian-born Sammy Wong.

After years working in a raft of business and community positions, and helping new migrants settle in the country, Wong was approached by political parties to run in New Zealand's first election under proportional representation.
She chose the National Party, saying she believed in its philosophy of private enterprise and individual rights.
"I believe the timing is right for Asian New Zealanders to stand up and participate," Wong declared.
"I feel very strongly that in New Zealand, we have only 3.6 million people and every human resource is valuable."
In New Zealand there has been an uneasy history between migrants and their new home. Until the early 1950s, Chinese immigrants were denied citizenship and the right to vote.

Race and immigration again erupted into the nation's consciousness this year when nationalistic New Zealand First leader Winston Peters accused some immigrants of "abusing New Zealand's hospitality" and promised to cut immigration "to the bone".
"It's the migrants who are already here who feel once again they seem to be targeted by the statements he used," said Wong.
Peters's comments and Australia's vigorous racism debate have provoked much reaction in Asia, but Wong challenges whether they are harmful for New Zealand's trade and relations in the region.

"I think it is sensational but let's not understate the intelligence of people in Asia. They understand New Zealand is a democratic country. A democratic country means you can't censor the freedom of speech so they...look beyond at what are the actions of the government, what are the actual policies."
Wong has extensive business contacts in Asia and hopes to use these to expand and enhance New Zealand's dealings there.

"Due to my election this time, the interest and excitement in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore has been tremendous. I can utilise that opportunity...for the benefit of New Zealand in terms of business and in terms of understanding.
"The only problem I have is time, I think," she smiled.
